description: ntfsclone - Efficiently clone, image, restore or rescue an NTFS

global_flags.description: is  only  useful for  extracting  metadata, saving or cloning a file system which was not properly unmounted from Windows.
op‐ tion  is allowed to be used only with the --metadata option, for the safety of user's data. The clusters which cause  the  incon‐ sistency are saved too.
ONLY  METADATA  (for  NTFS  experts).  Only  cloning to a (sparse) file is allowed, unless used the option --save-image is also used.  You can't metadata-only clone to a device.

serial  number is a 64 bit number used to identify the device during the mount‐ ing process, so it has to be changed to enable the original file system  and the clone to be mounted at the same time on the same computer.

the consistency of a saved image by simulating its restor‐ ing without writing anything. The NTFS data contained in the im‐ age is not tested.  The  option  --restore-image  must  also  be present,  and the options --output and --overwrite must be omit‐ ted.
If FILE is '-' then  clone to  the standard output. This option cannot be used for creating a partition, use --overwrite for an existing partition.
Clone NTFS to FILE, overwriting if exists
not wipe the timestamps, to be used only with the --metadata option.
Do not display any progress bars

dying disks,  can  be  rescued  the most efficiently way, with minimal stress on them. Ntfsclone works at the lowest, sector  level  in this  mode  too  thus more data can be rescued.  The contents of the unreadable sectors are filled by character '?' and  the  be‐ ginning of such sectors are marked by "BadSectoR\0".
argu‐ ment. If the SOURCE is '-' then the image is read from the stan‐ dard input.
output, e.g.  for  image  compression, encryption or streaming through a network.
is equivalent to -f -v .  Long named options can be abbreviated to any unique prefix of their name.
